comments.body:
From Rails integration standpoint, I've been adjusting the BrowseEverything branch to support certain aspects of Rails which raised errors during integration: https://github.com/samvera/browse-everything/commit/36aa1fde9863d8b1d9aa3d0cf945a251a3a93436. Integrating `activestorage` support for Rails 5.1.z required a bit more in terms of adjustment here: https://github.com/samvera/browse-everything/commit/c91218985566abea143195ecdae2b2a08ac86a58, as well as for https://github.com/pulibrary/figgy/commit/9e4cf594946d4cc7543d0dc1b32cba2f9d975095

I've also made some light improvements to the UI with https://github.com/samvera-labs/browse-everything-redux-react/commit/8ccd6c4666a731bbb010e482cc5cf93484c47746 and https://github.com/samvera-labs/browse-everything-redux-react/commit/c05c649bf1e6dc06603a47a99aeb7cfc41c4f429 (which starts down the path for supporting i18n).

Uploads now do work within BE, but I'm still working to integrate the UI with the "File Manager" button.

https://github.com/pulibrary/figgy/commit/dc9266f5386acafda4788804a559a288cbf2e930 and https://github.com/samvera/browse-everything/commit/61b352736b84a739193e72b5907b589a79c52573 were necessary in order to support single-file uploads using BE in the "File Manager" interface.

New Drop downs:

Accession
- Person (linked)
- Firm (linked)

Reference
- ~~Author (linked)~~ (is multiple, which we can't do at the moment)

princeton_ansible.title: Provision solr 8 boxes for use by catalog-staging

comments.body:
Migrating solr data to a new znode.

1. On each solr box, create a copy of /etc/defaults/solr.in.sh to /etc/defaults/_new_solr.in.sh. Update the `ZK_HOST` param to append the new znode. When it's time to edit this config file, you can just swap in the copy.
1. Stop solr on all boxes.
1. On one box only:
   1. Start a tmux session.
   1. `cd /opt/solr`
   1. `bin/solr zk mkroot /solr7 -z lib-zk-staging1:2181,lib-zk-staging2:2181,lib-zk-staging3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk cp -r zk:/clusterstate.json zk:/solr7/clusterstate.json -z lib-zk-staging1:2181,lib-zk-staging2:2181,lib-zk-staging3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk cp -r zk:/aliases.json zk:/solr7/aliases.json -z lib-zk-staging1:2181,lib-zk-staging2:2181,lib-zk-staging3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk cp -r zk:/live_nodes zk:/solr7/live_nodes -z lib-zk-staging1:2181,lib-zk-staging2:2181,lib-zk-staging3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk cp -r zk:/overseer zk:/solr7/overseer -z lib-zk-staging1:2181,lib-zk-staging2:2181,lib-zk-staging3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk cp -r zk:/overseer_elect zk:/solr7/overseer_elect -z lib-zk-staging1:2181,lib-zk-staging2:2181,lib-zk-staging3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk cp -r zk:/collections zk:/solr7/collections -z lib-zk-staging1:2181,lib-zk-staging2:2181,lib-zk-staging3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk cp -r zk:/configs zk:/solr7/configs -z lib-zk-staging1:2181,lib-zk-staging2:2181,lib-zk-staging3:2181`
   1. There are a couple others. Move everything except `/zookeeper`.
   1. Check the new znode contents: `bin/solr zk ls /solr7 -z lib-zk-staging1:2181,lib-zk-staging2:2181,lib-zk-staging3:2181`
   1. Delete those data from their old locations.
   1. `bin/solr zk rm -r /clusterstate.json -z lib-zk-staging1:2181,lib-zk-staging2:2181,lib-zk-staging3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk rm -r /aliases.json -z lib-zk-staging1:2181,lib-zk-staging2:2181,lib-zk-staging3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk rm -r /live_nodes -z lib-zk-staging1:2181,lib-zk-staging2:2181,lib-zk-staging3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk rm -r /overseer -z lib-zk-staging1:2181,lib-zk-staging2:2181,lib-zk-staging3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk rm -r /overseer_elect -z lib-zk-staging1:2181,lib-zk-staging2:2181,lib-zk-staging3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk rm -r /collections -z lib-zk-staging1:2181,lib-zk-staging2:2181,lib-zk-staging3:2181`
   1. `bin/solr zk rm -r /configs -z lib-zk-staging1:2181,lib-zk-staging2:2181,lib-zk-staging3:2181`
   1. Check the root node contents: `bin/solr zk ls / -z lib-zk-staging1:2181,lib-zk-staging2:2181,lib-zk-staging3:2181`
      1. The only contents should be `/zookeeper` and `/solr7`.
1. On each solr server, modify the solr.in.sh configs by swapping in the files you created in step 1. Ensure the owner remains `root:deploy`.
1. Start solr again.

pulfalight.title: Provide a hover-over key for any icons (i.e. box, folder, collection)
Collection level extents not displaying consistently.
Ability to search by box number and/or box and folder number

comments.body:
For dsc[2] containers, this should be fairly straightforward. All retrieval containers are described in the dsc[2], e.g. MC016 Box 26:
```
<c level="otherlevel" otherlevel="physicalitem" id="MC016_i2">
	<did>
		<container type="box">26</container>
		<unitid type="barcode">32101106254731</unitid>
		<physloc type="code">rcpph</physloc>
	</did>
</c>
```
Items or subcontainers contained in the retrieval container are referenced in the dsc[1] through the container/@parent, e.g. MC016 Box 26 Reel 6:
```
<container type="reel" parent="MC016_i2">6</container>
```

The situation is a little murkier for "classic" containers because it is not always evident whether a container is the retrieval container or a subcontainer. 

Other than box/folder pairs and multiple single-type containers, we currently have the following scenarios represented in our EAD files (though the Mudd dsc[2] Retro Project currently underway will significantly cut down on the variety and in particular on the various cabinet/drawer scenarios):

```
<did count="1249">
   <type>cabinet</type>
   <type>drawer</type>
   <type>folder</type>
</did>
<did count="734">
   <type>folder</type>
   <type>page</type>
</did>
<did count="660">

   <type>page</type>
</did>
<did count="650">

</did>

</did>

</did>

</did>

</did>

</did>

</did>

</did>

   <type>folder</type>

   <type>cabinet</type>
   <type>drawer</type>
</did>
<did count="2">
   <type>cabinet</type>
   <type>drawer</type>
   <type>folder</type>
   <type>box</type>
</did>
<did count="1">

   <type>reel</type>
</did>

</did>

   <type>folder</type>
</did>
<did count="1">
   <type>cabinet</type>
   <type>drawer</type>
   <type>folder</type>
   <type>cabinet</type>
   <type>drawer</type>
   <type>folder</type>

   <type>drawer</type>
   <type>folder</type>
</did>
<did count="1">
   <type>cabinet</type>
   <type>drawer</type>
   <type>box</type>
</did>
<did count="1">
   <type>folder</type>
   <type>cabinet</type>
   <type>drawer</type>
   <type>folder</type>
</did>
<did count="1">
   <type>box</type>
   <type>box</type>
   <type>box</type>
   <type>cabinet</type>
   <type>drawer</type>
   <type>folder</type>
</did>
<did count="1">
   <type>box</type>
   <type>folder</type>
   <type>box</type>
</did>
<did count="1">
   <type>cabinet</type>
   <type>folder</type>
   <type>drawer</type>
</did>
```

To follow up on @regineheberlein's description of "classic" containers being "murkier," we do keep a list of what is considered a ["container"](https://github.com/PrincetonUniversityLibrary/pulfa/blob/production/webapp/xsl/component2html.xsl#L617-L646) and ["subcontainer"](https://github.com/PrincetonUniversityLibrary/pulfa/blob/production/webapp/xsl/component2html.xsl#L813-L831) in the XSL. This helps us figure out what to send to Aeon when users request a component. 

The introduction of several new container types from Mudd has perhaps made this a bit more confusing, but I'm not sure we need them anymore, given the desire to implement the DSC2 approach for the renovation needs. (It would be helpful to remove them in the current system if they are no longer needed.)

@sdellis Indeed, except the container/subcontainer divide is not always consistent. Things like box + item or box + reel etc. are sometimes a container AND an item and sometimes an item IN a box. The barcoding project has actually helped a lot in flushing those out.
